unnormalised: A recent judgment by the Delhi High Court has brought Intellectual Property Law back into the spotlight. The case, *Sharma Industries vs. Gupta Enterprises*, revolved around a trademark infringement claim. Sharma Industries alleged that Gupta Enterprises was using a deceptively similar logo, causing confusion among consumers. The suit, filed under the Trademarks Act, 1999, Section 29, sought an injunction and damages amounting to Rs. 50 lakhs.

Sharma Industries alleged that Gupta Enterprises was using a deceptively similar logo, causing confusion among consumers. The suit, filed under the Trademarks Act, one thousand nine hundred and ninety nine, Section twenty nine, sought an injunction and damages amounting to rupee fifty lakhs.

unnormalised: The Court, in its ruling dated 27/10/2024, clarified several crucial aspects of trademark law. Justice Mehra emphasized the importance of "distinctiveness" in trademarks. He observed that a generic term cannot be monopolized and cited precedents like *Bata India Ltd. vs. Pyarelal & Co.* to support his judgment. The court also deliberated on the concept of "passing off," where a company misrepresents its goods as those of another, established brand.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the judgment addressed the issue of online trademark infringement, particularly on e-commerce platforms. With the proliferation of online marketplaces, the court stressed the need for stricter monitoring and accountability. Platforms like Flipkart and Amazon were urged to implement robust mechanisms to prevent the sale of counterfeit products. The judgment highlighted the relevance of Section 79 of the Information Technology Act, 2000, which deals with the liability of intermediaries.
